subject: US MARKETS WRAP - May 22nd: Stocks claw back losses on vaccine optimism
content:
• SNAPSHOT: Equities flat/higher, Treasuries flat, Dollar up, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: China introduces HK security bill; Fauci positive on MRNA vaccine; US to roll out mass testing
  • WEEK IN FOCUS: MON: Bank of Israel Monetary Policy Decision; German GDP Detailed (Q1); German Ifo Survey (May); New Zealand Trade Balance (Apr); US Memorial Day Holiday; UK Late May Bank Holiday TUE: Hungarian Monetary Policy Decision; US New Home sales (Apr) WED: Chinese Industrial Profits (Apr); US Richmond Fed (May) THU: BoK Monetary Policy Decision; German Flash CPI (May); EZ Sentiment Survey (May); US Durable Goods (Q1); GDP 2nd Estimate (Q1) and Core PCE (Q1) and Initial Jobless Claims (w/e 18 May) FRI: Japanese Unemployment Rate (Apr); German Retail Sales (Apr); EZ CPI (May); US PCE Price Index (Apr); Canadian GDP (Q1) SAT: Chinese NBS PMIs (May). Click here for full report.
  • CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY: Previewing BOK rate decision; Reviewing FOMC minutes, Fed’s Clarida, ECB minutes, BOJ, RBI, CBRT, SARB. Click here for full report.
  • NOTICE: Due to the upcoming UK bank holiday and US Memorial Day holiday on Monday 25th May, the desk will be running a reduced service alongside the subsequent market closures. See full details of service schedule and market closures here.

MARKET WRAP

US stocks are flat/higher, having dipped in overnight trade after Beijing announced a security law which could allow it to bypass Hong Kong lawmakers to crackdown on dissent, and that has hit risk sentiment, sending ES stocks to lows just above 2,900. Desks have noted the resilience of US stocks while those in China, for instance, saw significant downside. From there, losses were gradually pared, helped along by some constructive remarks from NIH Director Fauci on Moderna’s (MRNA) hopeful COVID vaccine. Stock futures ticked higher, gravitating towards its 5dma, where it was happy to stay after the Europeans left for the week. In the latter part of the US day, stock futures made a run for the session high, which some attributed to news that the White House was to launch a huge testing initiative. and a late surge took the ES back to HOD. Yields were lower along the Treasury curve, with a modest flattening bias. The crude complex is still suffering losses, however, with some desk mindful of what US/China tensions will mean for the world’s largest crude importer from the demand-side of the equation. The dollar is green for a second day, and ends the week in the red; the broader (approx.) 99-101 range is still intact. Action was thinner in the latter part of the session as players left early for the long weekend (desk hours and market closures here).

VACCINE

MRNA/GILD: NIH Dr. Fauci, speaking to NPR, said that having looked at the Moderna (MRNA) data itself, it was quite promising, though he acknowledged that the full data had not been peer reviewed; still, he is “cautiously optimistic” that the vaccine could be ready to deploy at the end of 2020 or early 2021. Fauci confirmed the data would be peer reviewed within weeks. To recap, on Monday the Phase 1 MRNA vaccine results were described by Moderna to be positive, which saw risk appetite emboldened. However, on Tuesday, a STAT News article highlighting the scientific limits of the announcement, such as the small 8-person sample size, making it near impossible to draw conclusions at this stage. Later, Fauci on Gilead’s (GILD) remdesivir stated that the study was statistically significant, although the results were modest, adding we can build on the success of remdesivir. Elsewhere, US doctors and others are calling for the data that convinced health regulators to authorise emergency use of Gilead’s (GILD) remdesivir to be released.

TESTING: US will reportedly test experimental coronavirus vaccines in 100k people or more, adding the vaccine candidate from Oxford University may be tested side by side with Moderna's (MRNA) from July, while Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Merck (MRK) and Sanofi (SAN FP), vaccines could be added in the summer.

HYDROXYCHLOROQUINE: Hydroxycholoroquine test results published in The Lancet journal, across 96k patients, showed that there was no significant difference in COVID patients treated with the drug, according to Washington Post. David Maron, director of preventive cardiology at the Stanford University School of Medicine, said that “these findings provide absolutely no reason for optimism that these drugs might be useful in the prevention or treatment of covid-19”. It showed that patients were more likely to suffer irregular heart-beat rhythms. The former top FDA official said it is now time to revoke the emergency FDA authorisation for the drug. Reminder, the use of hydroxychloroquine saw a warning from the FDA and the NIH did not recommend using the drug.

OXFORD UNIVERSITY: AstraZeneca (AZN LN) and Oxford University are to start Phase II/III human trials for COVID-19 vaccine. The next study will enrol up to 10.26k adults and children and involve a number of partners across the country.

ASIA-PAC

CHINA NPC: China Premier Li Keqiang announced Beijing would scrap its growth target this year and introduced national security law which allows it to bypass Hong Kong's lawmakers, which pro-democracy activists fear it could mean the effective end of Hong Kong’s autonomy. In terms of the economic metrics, it abandoned its 2020 GDP target due to the COVID19 pandemic and uncertainties. It is, however, targeting a fiscal deficit of 3.6%/GDP (from 2.8% in 2019), which some analysts have taken as a sign that China does not intend to significantly ramp up fiscal stimulus. China aims to create 9mln jobs in 2020 (it’s 2019 target was 11mln), and joblessness will be capped at 6%. China also fixed the quota on local-government special bond issuance at CNY 3.75trln (prev. CNY 2.15trln). It will debut 1trln of special treasury bonds in 2020, and transfer CNY 2trln raised from the bigger 2020 budget deficit and special anti-coronavirus treasury bonds to local governments, Reuters reported. These local government bonds could be used to fund infrastructure projects, while special treasury bonds could be used to support firms and regions hit by the outbreak. A Reuters calculation suggests these fiscal measures are worth about 4.1% of china's GDP.

NATIONAL SECURITY LAW: The security law, which weighed on sentiment, could allow China to bypass lawmakers in Hong Kong thus still having some control of the country which goes against the “one country, two systems” principle, which has in the past led to widespread protests. The law has also faced criticism from the US where President Trump stated the US would have a very strong reaction, while the Senate introduced a bill that would sanction Chinese officials and entities who enforce the new national security laws. The NPC Committee says as far as they know, the Hong Kong legislation is ready, which will be passed in the next meeting of the NPC Standing Committee, which could be passed into law after resolutions are voted on May 28th, according to Global Times. Following the law, White House Economic Adviser Hassett noted that the developments in Hong Kong will be very bad for the Chinese economy.

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB MINUTES: The account of the ECB's April meeting passed with little fanfare, with the main takeaway being that the Governing Council is "fully prepared to increase the size of the PEPP and adjust its composition by as much as necessary and for as long as needed"; a line that concluded the policy statement last month. In terms of the current stock of actions, however, "the view was widely shared that the Governing Council’s monetary policy measures taken in March, and reinforced by decisions taken on the collateral framework in April, had provided forceful monetary accommodation". That said (and in-fitting with communications from the Bank), it was judged that monetary policy alone could not address some of the Eurozone's issues and fiscal authorities needed to play their role in combating the crisis. As such, any developments on the Eurozone Recovery Fund could play a key role in shaping the narrative ahead of the ECB's next meeting on the 4th June. Also at the June meeting, market participants will be presented with the latest round of staff economic projections, ahead of which, the account revealed that "it was generally considered that, of the three scenarios presented, the 'mild' scenario was probably already too optimistic". Overall, the account provided little in the way of fresh insight into the current train of thought on the Governing Council, however, given the apparent lack of dissent among policymakers, it appears that the beginning of Lagarde's tenure is a more united one than the end of Draghi's.

BOE: BoE Deputy Governor Ramsden says it is possible BoE will do more QE at the June meeting or subsequently. He joined Bailey, Haldane and Tenreyo on NIRP commentary, stating it is reasonable to have an open mind on negative rates but it is complex. Ramsden added there is plenty of headroom for conventional QE Gilt purchases. He noted the UK economic upturn will be less sharp than downturn, adding indicators suggests Q2 GDP could fall slightly less than BoE's May scenario, but it is still early days. The Deputy Governor does not see a case for purchase of linkers or Gilts maturing under 3yrs.

FIXED INCOME

T-Note futures (M0) settle 3 ticks higher at 139-05

The TPLEX bull-flattened to end the week as participants withdrew risk exposure ahead of the long weekend, rising US-China tensions over Hong Kong, and disappointing China growth/stimulus targets. By settlement, 2s unchanged at 0.17% and 30s -3bps at 1.37%. Yields made their lows overnight, alongside equity futures, on the tails of the lacklustre China deficit target and lack of concrete GDP target. Additionally, China continues to move ahead with its Hong Kong security law – seeing the Hang Seng Index trade with losses over 7% – which amplifies the already strained Sino-US relations. However, as the US session came into the horizon, equity futures and yields began to climb back higher finding support from Fauci comments – the overnight US 10-year low stood at just below 63bp and currently stands at 66bp – and after the US equity open, yields traded rangebound through till settlement. Corporate issuance was light today as activity quiets down going into the holiday weekend. Meanwhile, the Fed’s week-ahead Treasury/TIPS purchase schedule, which again cut daily purchases to USD 5bln per day (prev. 6bln), failed to alter the dial in price action. Note, UST June futures are now entering their roll period, with First Intention next Thursday evening (May 28th) – based on June/September OI, the process is already 25% complete – thus an element of book squaring is likely to be seen in the tape action in the coming sessions. Furthermore, as month-end rebalancing approaches, the Bloomberg Barclays UST Aggregate index is due to extend by 0.12-years (vs 12-month average of 0.08-year), thus supporting USTs into June.

NY FED: The NY Fed cut its Treasuries/TIPS purchases to USD 20bln a week from USD 30bln; USD 5bln per day for next week (prev. USD 6bln). Click here to see next week’s schedule

  • 0-2.25 year: USD 6.5bln (prev. USD 9.5bln) (-32% W/W)
  • 2.25-4.5: USD 4bln (prev. USD 6bln) (-33% W/W)
  • 4.5-7 year: USD 3bln (prev. USD 4.5bln) (-33% W/W)
  • 7-20 year: USD 2bln (prev. USD 3bln) (-33% W/W)
  • 20-30 year: USD 2.5bln (prev. USD 4bln) (-38% W/W)
  • TIPS 1-7.5 year: USD 1bln (prev. USD 1.5bln) (-33% W/W)
  • TIPS 7.5-30 year: USD 1bln (prev. USD 1.5bln) (-33% W/W)

CRUDE

WTI (N0) SETTLES USD 0.67 LOWER AT USD 33.25; BRENT (N0) SETTLES USD 0.93 LOWER AT USD 35.13; BRENT (Q0) SETTLES USD -0.75 LOWER AT USD 35.66.

Energy markets traded lower on Friday, paring some of their strength seen this week amid participants’ risk appetite declining ahead of the long weekend. The losses came overnight in APAC trade as sentiment got knocked after China/US tensions deteriorated and the announced Chinese budget deficit target was less than some had expected, in addition to the lack of a specific GDP target. Furthermore, with Hong Kong tensions back in the limelight, and an impressive six-day rally in crude, many longs are likely to close positions to limit their risk exposure over the long weekend. Elsewhere today, OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said OPEC+ members must remain committed to production cuts despite signs oil demand is starting to recover; “there are tentative signs of recovery and we believe the worst is behind us.” Meanwhile, the latest US Baker Hughes rig count (w/e 22nd May) saw oil rigs -21 at 237, nat gas. unchanged at 79, and total rigs -21 at 318 – note that Y/Y, total rigs have fallen by 665.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.2% at 2,955, NDX +0.4% at 9,414, DJIA -0.0% at 24,465.

SECTORS: Energy -0.6%, materials -0.2%, industrials -0.2%, consumer discretionary -0.2%, consumer staples +0.3%, healthcare +0.2%, financials -0.3%, IT +0.4%, telecoms +0.5%, utilities +1.1%

EUROPE CLOSES: EURO STOXX 50 (+0.1%) at 2907, FTSE 100 (-0.4%) at 5991, DAX (+0.1%) at 11,051, CAC 40 (+0.1%) at 4451, IBEX 35 (+0.1%) at 6693, FTSE MIB (+1.3%) at 17,305, SMI (-1.1%) at 9684

NVIDIA: Nvidia (NVDA) overall saw a solid report, beating on top and bottom line, authorizing a USD 7.24bln share repurchase programme while maintaining its dividend commitment.  Data Center revenue also topped estimates. Its gaming revenue also beat, although was still down Q/Q & Y/Y; perhaps disappointing some given the large increase in other gaming names. GM was slightly lower than expected. NVDA saw choppy trade after its release but trade higher as the market recovers from overnight lows. Overall a solid report, although analysts suggest given the run NVDA has seen recently perhaps the figures were not enough to continue the trend further. UBS raised its PT on the name to USD 400 from USD 330 noting how the how the relationship of its GPU and CPU performance overall is becoming decoupled, which the desk suggests “NVDA can bring more flexible computing solutions to customers on a massive scale”.

EARNINGS: Deere (DE) beat on EPS and revenue but it expects global equipment sales to fall 30-40% this year. Foot Locker (FL) missed on EPS and revenue while SSS also fared worse and it temporarily suspended its dividend. Alibaba (BABA) beat on EPS and revenue driven by an increase in online purchases during lockdown, while MAU’s rose to 846mln and annual active users rose to 726mln. BABA is keeping a close eye on the US Senator Bill on Chinese Co.’s. Hewlett Packard (HPE) missed on EPS and revenue; announced a cost cutting plan to save USD 1bln by 2022. Intuit (INTU) missed on EPS and revenue after the IRS tax filing deadline hampered its business as it caused millions of filings to shift to later in the season.

STOCK SPECIFICS: eBay’s (EBAY) classified advertisement business reportedly received a bid from Germany’s Axel Springer (SPR GY), backed by KKR (KKR), according to FT sources. Note, initial reports that the business was for sale (back in February), suggested the unit could be worth as much as USD 10bln. General Motors (GM) reportedly delayed the resumption of the second shift at three of its truck plants in North America that were initially scheduled for Monday. Meanwhile, separate reports noted a shortage of parts in Mexico is hampering its plans to increase production of its pickup trucks. Amazon (AMZN) plans to hire 50k workers in India. IBM (IBM) is reportedly set to cut an unspecified number of jobs, the first reduction of workers under its new CEO. Lululemon (LULU) announced it has reopened over 150 retail locations and plans to open 200 more over the next two weeks while stores will have new safety/cleansing guidelines. BestBuy (BBY) announced it plans to reopen roughly 600 stores to the public by June 13th. KKR (KKR) took a stake in US Foods (USFD). Irish authorities have submitted draft decision of probe into Twitter (TWTR) to EU states; has sent prelim draft to Facebook (FB) owned Whatsapp; says making progress in three other investigations relating to FB.

WEEKLY FX WRAP

CURRENCY MARKETS BEHOLDEN TO BREWING ANGST BETWEEN BEIJING AND WASHINGTON

USD: Friday’s Dollar-G10 standings and directional moves provide a pretty accurate picture of the mood as a whole if not the complete story given intermittent deviations and distractions from the main theme driving sentiment in the form of a further deterioration in US-China relations regarding COVID-19, but expanding to encompass a host of other contentious issues. On that note, the latest intervention from Beijing at the NPC to pass legislation against perceived national security threats in Hong Kong has irked Washington to the degree of condemnation and China’s Foreign Ministry has threatened to retaliate if the US tries to oppress the country via sanctions. The simmering tensions and potential risk to trade, military and all existing pacts between the 2 nations has dampened sentiment after an optimistic start to the week forged on global economies reopening and daily rates of coronavirus infections/fatalities continuing to slow, in the main. Hence, the DXY is back in the ascendency from lowly beginnings and towards the upper end of 100.470-99.001 extremes, albeit unable to reclaim 100.000 after more data and survey-based evidence of the fallout from the global pandemic, like weekly jobless claims for the May NFP reporting period pushing the total since the outbreak up to almost 40 mn. For the record, Fed rhetoric including several speeches from chair Powell was largely consistent with guidance at the last policy meeting and reaffirmed via the minutes, but the clear message remains that while more stimulus is likely to be needed (monetary and fiscal), NIRP is not on the current agenda given mixed assessments about the effectiveness of negative rates.

AUD, CAD, NZD: The commodity bloc has been volatile amidst swings in underlying prices and overall sentiment, but with some specific and independent inputs via macro releases and Central Bank commentary. In short, the hard data has been bad, though not unexpected, but the RBA and RBNZ have both intimated there is more in the tool-kit if required including additional QE, rate cuts and other more liquidity focused measures, just not on the very near term agenda as they shift to a wait-and-see stance. Meanwhile, the Loonie has been mostly supported by the strengthening recovery in crude that reached a crescendo over the June WTI contract expiry in start contrast to the previous front month, but has waned into the long US (and UK) holiday weekend, and a sharp slide in retail sales (akin to elsewhere, and for Australia a record drop) has undermined the Cad as well. Back down under, the Aussie also had to acknowledge, if not accept a Fitch outlook downgrade from stable to negative that could see the sovereign lose its top-notch AAA ratings status, in theory, on top of higher export tariffs on key goods to China.

EUR, GBP: The Euro and Pound have also witnessed very choppy trading conditions with Eur/Usd reaching dizzy 1.1000+ heights on a combination of encouraging Eurozone preliminary PMIs (pan indices more so than German or French) and follow-through from the big 2 finally agreeing that joint EU debt should contribute towards the financing of the Eur500 bn rescue fund. However, the headline pair is back below 1.0900 vs a circa 1.0800 low awaiting final approval for the fiscal support next week amidst more ECB pledges that additional QE will be delivered (and perhaps as soon as June) if required, and with full use of APP/PEPP flexibility irrespective of the German legal ruling on proportionality. Elsewhere, the bearish seasonal spell is still casting shadows over Sterling, with Cable down below 1.2100 and Eur/Gbp up to almost 0.9000 at one stage, but the Pound also had to digest dire UK jobs, retail sales and benign inflation vs improvements in PMI plus dovish BoE rhetoric from Haldane in particular, but also other MPC members like Tenreyro and Governor Bailey all not ruling out NIRP even though the concept of sub-zero rates is complex.

SCANDI, EM: Aside from the aforementioned oil renaissance that lasted until today, bullish technical impulses have carried the Swedish and Norwegian Crowns to fresh pinnacles vs the Euro, and EMs remain on course to register net gains against the Dollar irrespective of a mixed end to the week. Retracement and ongoing corrections from record or multi-year troughs have prompted more short covering, while the Brl has benefited from ramped up intervention. However, 50 bp rate cuts have hampered the Try and Zar to varying degrees and the Rub has been undermined by dovish CBR remarks from the Governor intimating at the prospect of full point ease in June, in stark contrast to the Idr that took an unexpected 40 bp reduction from the RBI effectively in stride. Last, but by no means least, the Yuan has depreciated on the rising acrimony between China and the US noted above, with Usd/Cnh over 7.1600 earlier and within a whisker of March highs around 7.1650 after the NPC omitted to set an official 2020 GDP target, as speculated, but still worrying in terms of the global economy given 2nd wave virus risks.

Weekly FX Wrap: currency markets beholden to brewing angst between Beijing and Washington
content:
USD

Friday’s Dollar-G10 standings and directional moves provide a pretty accurate picture of the mood as a whole if not the complete story given intermittent deviations and distractions from the main theme driving sentiment in the form of a further deterioration in US-China relations regarding COVID-19, but expanding to encompass a host of other contentious issues. On that note, the latest intervention from Beijing at the NPC to pass legislation against perceived national security threats in Hong Kong has irked Washington to the degree of condemnation and China’s Foreign Ministry has threatened to retaliate if the US tries to oppress the country via sanctions. The simmering tensions and potential risk to trade, military and all existing pacts between the 2 nations has dampened sentiment after an optimistic start to the week forged on global economies reopening and daily rates of coronavirus infections/fatalities continuing to slow, in the main. Hence, the DXY is back in the ascendency from lowly beginnings and towards the upper end of 100.470-99.001 extremes, albeit unable to reclaim 100.000 after more data and survey-based evidence of the fallout from the global pandemic, like weekly jobless claims for the May NFP reporting period pushing the total since the outbreak up to almost 40 mn. For the record, Fed rhetoric including several speeches from chair Powell was largely consistent with guidance at the last policy meeting and reaffirmed via the minutes, but the clear message remains that while more stimulus is likely to be needed (monetary and fiscal), NIRP is not on the current agenda given mixed assessments about the effectiveness of negative rates.

AUD/CAD/NZD 

The commodity bloc has been volatile amidst swings in underlying prices and overall sentiment, but with some specific and independent inputs via macro releases and Central Bank commentary. In short, the hard data has been bad, though not unexpected, but the RBA and RBNZ have both intimated there is more in the tool-kit if required including additional QE, rate cuts and other more liquidity focused measures, just not on the very near term agenda as they shift to a wait-and-see stance. Meanwhile, the Loonie has been mostly supported by the strengthening recovery in crude that reached a crescendo over the June WTI contract expiry in start contrast to the previous front month, but has waned into the long US (and UK) holiday weekend, and a sharp slide in retail sales (akin to elsewhere, and for Australia a record drop) has undermined the Cad as well. Back down under, the Aussie also had to acknowledge, if not accept a Fitch outlook downgrade from stable to negative that could see the sovereign lose its top-notch AAA ratings status, in theory, on top of higher export tariffs on key goods to China.

EUR/GBP

The Euro and Pound have also witnessed very choppy trading conditions with Eur/Usd reaching dizzy 1.1000+ heights on a combination of encouraging Eurozone preliminary PMIs (pan indices more so than German or French) and follow-through from the big 2 finally agreeing that joint EU debt should contribute towards the financing of the Eur500 bn rescue fund. However, the headline pair is back below 1.0900 vs a circa 1.0800 low awaiting final approval for the fiscal support next week amidst more ECB pledges that additional QE will be delivered (and perhaps as soon as June) if required, and with full use of APP/PEPP flexibility irrespective of the German legal ruling on proportionality. Elsewhere, the bearish seasonal spell is still casting shadows over Sterling, with Cable down below 1.2100 and Eur/Gbp up to almost 0.9000 at one stage, but the Pound also had to digest dire UK jobs, retail sales and benign inflation vs improvements in PMI plus dovish BoE rhetoric from Haldane in particular, but also other MPC members like Tenreyro and Governor Bailey all not ruling out NIRP even though the concept of sub-zero rates is complex.

SCANDI/EM

Aside from the aforementioned oil renaissance that lasted until today, bullish technical impulses have carried the Swedish and Norwegian Crowns to fresh pinnacles vs the Euro, and EMs remain on course to register net gains against the Dollar irrespective of a mixed end to the week. Retracement and ongoing corrections from record or multi-year troughs have prompted more short covering, while the Brl has benefited from ramped up intervention. However, 50 bp rate cuts have hampered the Try and Zar to varying degrees and the Rub has been undermined by dovish CBR remarks from the Governor intimating at the prospect of full point ease in June, in stark contrast to the Idr that took an unexpected 40 bp reduction from the RBI effectively in stride. Last, but by no means least, the Yuan has depreciated on the rising acrimony between China and the US noted above, with Usd/Cnh over 7.1600 earlier and within a whisker of March highs around 7.1650 after the NPC omitted to set an official 2020 GDP target, as speculated, but still worrying in terms of the global economy given 2nd wave virus risks.

US EQUITY OPEN: Indices open in the red; Energy leads losses amid lower oil prices
analysis_details:
SNAPSHOT: US equities have opened in the red, following the leads in Europe and Asia, after risk-off themes developed overnight; China announced a security law that could allow it to bypass lawmakers in Hong Kong. In the pre-market, some positive commentary from the NIH’s Fauci saw futures pare losses, though sentiment still remains fragile. Most sectors open in the red, although Real Estate is positive while defensives, Staples and Utilities, are flat; as is Technology. Energy underperforms amid a fall in oil prices, and Financials are also lower. Treasuries are bull-flattening, the dollar is up for a second day, putting pressure on EMFX and risk sensitive currencies, and even oil is taking its cues from the risk complex today despite bullish inventory data over the last two weeks. The ECB minutes saw little new information; reiterated its pledge to increase the size and adjust the composition of its PEPP if required. Ahead, the NY Fed will announce next week's asset purchase schedule at 1400 EDT/1900 BST (preview); we expect liquidity conditions to tail-off in the afternoon as US and UK players eye a long-weekend.

NOTICE: Due to the upcoming UK bank holiday and US Memorial Day holiday on Monday 25th May, the desk will be running a reduced service alongside the subsequent market closures. See full details of service schedule and market closures here.

NVIDIA: Nvidia (NVDA) overall saw a solid report, beating on top and bottom line, authorizing a USD 7.24bln share repurchase programme while maintaining its dividend commitment.  Data Center revenue also topped estimates. Its gaming revenue also beat, although was still down Q/Q & Y/Y; perhaps disappointing some given the large increase in other gaming names. GM was slightly lower than expected. NVDA saw choppy trade after its release but trade higher as the market recovers from overnight lows. Overall a solid report, although analysts suggest given the run NVDA has seen recently perhaps the figures were not enough to continue the trend further. UBS raised its PT on the name to USD 400 from USD 330 noting how the how the relationship of its GPU and CPU performance overall is becoming decoupled, which the desk suggests “NVDA can bring more flexible computing solutions to customers on a massive scale”.

EARNINGS: Deere (DE) beat on EPS and revenue but it expects global equipment sales to fall 30-40% this year. Foot Locker (FL) missed on EPS and revenue while SSS also fared worse and it temporarily suspended its dividend. Alibaba (BABA) beat on EPS and revenue driven by an increase in online purchases during lockdown, while MAU’s rose to 846mln and annual active users rose to 726mln. BABA is keeping a close eye on the US Senator Bill on Chinese Co.’s. Hewlett Packard (HPE) missed on EPS and revenue; announced a cost cutting plan to save USD 1bln by 2022. Intuit (INTU) missed on EPS and revenue after the IRS tax filing deadline hampered its business as it caused millions of filings to shift to later in the season.

STOCK SPECIFICS: US doctors and others are calling for the data that convinced health regulators to authorise emergency use of Gilead’s (GILD) remdesivir to be released. Amazon (AMZN) plans to hire 50k workers in India. IBM (IBM) is reportedly set to cut an unspecified number of jobs, the first reduction of workers under its new CEO. Lululemon (LULU) announced it has reopened over 150 retail locations and plans to open 200 more over the next two weeks while stores will have new safety/cleansing guidelines. BestBuy (BBY) announced it plans to reopen roughly 600 stores to the public by June 13th. KKR (KKR) took a stake in US Foods (USFD).

ES LEVELS: 3,135 (78.6% Feb hi-Mar lo), 2,998 (200dma), 2,976.25 (May hi), 2,950-53 (volume profile), 2,947-50 (FY 20 and FY 21 exp EPS and p/e implied valuations), 2,940 (5dma), 2,930 (61.8% Feb hi-Mar lo), 2,917-2,923, 2,900-10 (volume profile), 2,900 (8dma), 2,894 (13dma), 2,850 (this week lo).

FUND FLOWS: Bank of America’s weekly fund flow analysis of EPFR data reveals that investor cash stockpiling see during the COVID outbreak has peaked, with cash focussed funds seeing outflows of USD 5.9bln in the week, the first outflows since mid-February; equity funds saw outflows of USD 7.6bln, BofA says, the first decline in 12-weeks, and bond funds saw the largest inflows in 13-weeks, while gold funds saw inflows of USD 3.5bln, a record.

GROWTH, MOMENTUM STILL PREFERRED: US equities have this week printed fresh May highs earlier in the week, and then slumped in the latter part as US/China risk sentiment deteriorated. Nomura's quants think the improvement in sentiment will not take a breather, although points out that technically foreseeable risk-off phases tend to not last too long: "Bearish investors that had been counting on a stock market double dip already appear to be backing out of the trades they had made on that assumption, and it seems that few investors are attempting to chase the market down," the bank says, "it may make sense for now to buy whatever dips come along and wait to see what happens." Nomura says that CTAs seem reticent to tweak positions much, and NDX futures are the only US equity futures where CTAs have already gone back to accumulating longs. "Given that the NASDAQ 100 is the only US stock market index in a clear uptrend, we soon expect to see CTAs plainly building up their net long position again, perhaps even next week although possibly not until 5 June." Growth and momentum appear to be the preferred strategies, the quants say, given that 10-year yields are beneath what it calls the 'trigger line' of 0.84% and US economic surprises are not yet improving, investors seem to be sticking with momentum for a lack of better alternatives. Nomura sees global macro hedge funds actively staking out new positions, premised on a main scenario in which the US-China stand-off intensifies. "This leaves hedge funds fairly neutrally positioned with regard to US-China risk; a flare-up in the stand-off still stands as a tail risk, however, and should this risk materialise, these hedge funds could end up taking a punch that is difficult to roll with." Meanwhile, CTA exposure to China-related equity futures (total for China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan) is essentially flat, Nomura says, and it sees no increase in technically driven downside trades. "However, if we look at the relative performance of cyclicals over defensives in cash equity markets, we find that the pick-up in the performance of cyclicals has been weak in Asia, and what this suggests to us that that the market thinks the US economy will recover more quickly than the economies of Asia."

CHINA NATIONAL SECURITY LAW: The security law, which weighed on sentiment, could allow China to bypass lawmakers in Hong Kong thus still having some control of the country which goes against the “one country, two systems” principle, which has in the past led to widespread protests. The law has also faced criticism from the US where President Trump stated the US would have a very strong reaction, while the Senate introduced a bill that would sanction Chinese officials and entities who enforce the new national security laws.

May 22nd, 2020: NVDA & DE beat, Fauci positive on MRNA vaccine

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1400BST/0800CDT recapping all the overnight equity news

  • US equity futures were under pressure overnight after China announced a security law that could allow it to bypass lawmakers in Hong Kong thus still having some control of the country and goes against the “once country, two systems” principle, which has in the past led to widespread protests. The law has also faced criticism from the US where President Trump stated the US would have a very strong reaction, while the Senate introduced a bill that would sanction Chinese officials and entities who enforce the new national security laws. However, the downside has since pared back after NIH Dr. Fauci spoke positively on MRNA’s vaccine candidate, noting the data itself is quite promising, and that he was cautiously optimistic a vaccine could be ready to deploy by the end of the year or early 2021.

DOW JONES

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) announced it plans to hire up to 50,000 workers in India to meet the higher demand in the country.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – KKR (KRR) is the latest to invest in India’s Digital Co. Jio Platforms, which Facebook (FB) recently purchased a stake in.
  • Gilead Sciences (GILD) (Health Care/Biotechnology) – US doctors and others are calling for the data that convinced health regulators to authorise emergency use of remdesivir to be released.
  • Intuit Inc. (INTU) (Information Technology/Internet Software & Services) Q3 20 (USD): EPS 4.49 (exp. 4.68), Revenue 3.0bln (exp. 3.05bln). Co. notes the IRS tax filing deadline extension caused millions of tax filing to shift later in the season, seeing revenue -8% in the Quarter. Consumer Group revenue -15%, Small Business, and Self-Employed Group revenue +11%, Small Business Online Ecosystem revenue +28%.
  • Lululemon (LULU) (Consumer Discretionary/Textiles, Apparel & Luxury Goods) announced it has reopened over 150 retail locations and plans to open 200 more over the next two weeks while stores will have new safety/cleansing guidelines.
  • Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) Q1 20 (USD): Adj. EPS 1.80 (exp. 1.69), Revenue 3.1bln (exp. 3.0bln); authorised USD 7.24bln in share repurchases through Dec. 2022, but it is evaluating the timing of share repurchases. Maintains dividend commitment. Revenue Breakdown: DCG: 1.14bln (exp. 1.07bln), Gaming revenue 1.34bln (exp. 1.29bln; -10% Q/Q, -27% Y/Y). Guidance Q2 revenue view 3.65bln (+/- 2% (exp. 3.28bln). GM: 65.1% (exp. 65.4%). Expects MLNX acquisition to contribute a low-teens percentage of combined Q2 revenue. NVDA saw choppy trade and is currently trading with modest gains in the pre-market after being negative post the release. Given the solid guidance and Q1 metrics, analysts have highlighted that NVDA stock has had a very good run recently therefore may not have been enough to continue gains. RBC note, however, the MLNX guide was light, while UBS raise the PT on the Co highlighting how the relationship of its GPU and CPU performance overall is becoming decoupled, which the desk notes “NVDA can bring more flexible computing solutions to customers on a massive scale.” During the conference call, its CEO noted that AI is at its very early stages, adding the cloud computing journey has a long way to go.

  • Starbucks Corp. (SBUX) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) announced over 85% of its US stores are open; it is now to introduce a new summer food and drink menu.

S&P 500

subject: Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam says the gov't does not expect protests to end
analysis_details:

(Newswires)

subject: UK COVID-19 death toll rises to 36,393 (Prev. 36,042); deaths rise by 351 vs. yesterday's 338. Case count rises 3,287 vs. prev. 2,615 increase
Fixed and FX latest: debt barely treading water, but Dollar still trending higher
content: Core EU bonds have retreated further from best levels with Bunds back down near overnight Eurex lows and Gilts just off a fresh Liffe base at 138.43 vs Thursday’s 138.47 close having been just over ½ point ahead at one stage. However, USTs remain firm and the curve flatter ahead of the long holiday weekend and the final week of May against the backdrop of a bullish 0.12 year index extension, while the Dollar is grinding higher again with the DXY retesting earlier 98.878 peaks, as Usd/Cad climbs in wake of Canadian retail sales data. Note also, the Eur/Usd is hovering around 1.0900 and well off yesterday’s 1.1000+ highs after downbeat/dovish ECB minutes underscored a willingness to deliver more QE stimulus, if needed.

subject: Hydroxycholoroquine test results published in The Lancet journal, across 96k patients, showed that there was no significant difference in COVID patients treated with the drug, according to Washington Post
content:
• David Maron, director of preventive cardiology at the Stanford University School of Medicine, said that “these findings provide absolutely no reason for optimism that these drugs might be useful in the prevention or treatment of covid-19.”
  • Showed that patients were more likely to suffer irregular heart beat rhythms
  • Former top FDA official said it is now time to revoke the emergency FDA authorisation for the drug
  • Via WP
analysis_details: • Note, this study is based on a retrospective analysis of medical records, not a controlled study in which patients are divided randomly into treatment groups.

content:
• It was generally considered that, of the three scenarios presented, the “mild” scenario was probably already too optimistic.
  • The view was widely shared that the Governing Council’s monetary policy measures taken in March, and reinforced by decisions taken on the collateral framework in April, had provided forceful monetary accommodation
  • It was cautioned that monetary policy was not able to address these problems on its own and that fiscal policy also needed to play an essential role.
  • Looking beyond the immediate disruption stemming from the coronavirus pandemic, euro area growth was expected to resume as the containment measures were gradually lifted, supported by favourable financing conditions, the euro area fiscal stance and a resumption of global activity.
  • Link

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 22nd May 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • China’s NPC meeting confirmed no GDP target for 2020 & reiterated intentions to implement the Phase One US-China deal
  • China's draft Hong Kong legislation stated that Hong Kong should finish enacting as soon as possible the regulations in basic law regarding national security; HK activists reportedly intend to protest this
  • APAC indices were heavily weighed upon on the NPC & HK newsflow, sentiment which has hit European bourses & US futures; albeit, currently off lows
  • Fixed is firmer and USD outperforms on safe-haven demand to the detriment of major peers
  • BoJ left rates U/C but implemented a new loan scheme to support small/medium firms while the RBI cut rates by 40bp in an emergency move
  • President Trump said he thinks the US will need more fiscal stimulus, could be one more shot of stimulus and would not close the country if a second wave occurred
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB Minutes, ECB’s Lane & China’s NPC Meeting

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

AFP tweeted there were 1255 deaths in US from coronavirus in 24 hours citing the Johns Hopkins tracker. (Newswires/AFP/Twitter)

President Trump said he thinks the US will need more fiscal stimulus and that there could be one more nice shot of stimulus post coronavirus outbreak, while he stated he will not close the country if a second wave of virus hits. (Newswires)

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said it is highly likely there will be another rescue package and it is important to incentivize people to work, while he added the Senate is in the same place as the White House and the next coronavirus stimulus package is not far off. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) and Oxford University are to start Phase II/III human trials for COVID-19 vaccine, next study is to enrol up to 10.26k adults and children and involve number of partners across the country. (Newswires)

Fujifilm (4901 JT) - declined to comment on the potential timeline for the approval of Avigan to combat COVID-19. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian indices weakened as markets digested today's key events including the BoJ off-schedule meeting and start of China's NPC where it omitted setting a GDP growth target for this year due to the coronavirus pandemic, as well as uncertainties surrounding economy and trade. ASX 200 (-1.0%) declined with energy names pressured by an aggressive pullback in oil prices and with sentiment subdued after Fitch revised its outlook on Australia’s sovereign rating to negative from stable, while Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) suffered the ill-effects of a firmer currency despite the BoJ’s announcement of a new measure to boost lending to small and mid-sized businesses impacted by the coronavirus in which it set aside JPY 75tln for its new loan programme but which was widely anticipated. Hang Seng (-5.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.4%) were lower amid the start of China’s Two Sessions conclave where the Government Work Report refrained from setting an economic growth target but pledged to reduce tax and fee burdens for companies by CNY 2.5tln this year and use several tools to keep liquidity ample. Furthermore, the losses in Hong Kong were exacerbated after China’s attempts to tighten its grip on the Special Administrative Region through a new national security law, and is likely to stoke further unrest for the region which had already been mired by months of protests since the middle of last year. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively uninspired with only mild upside seen despite the downbeat risk tone and upside in T-notes, while the conclusion of the BoJ’s emergency meeting and announcement of a new lending scheme also failed to spur any meaningful price action.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0939 vs. Exp. 7.0969 (Prev. 7.0868)

Chinese Premier Li announced the Government Work Report did not contain a GDP target for 2020 citing global pandemic and uncertainties for global economy and trade, but stated that China will make policy more flexible and will use policy tools such as open market operations, interest rate cut, RRR cut, re-lending and re-discount to keep liquidity reasonably ample. Furthermore, Li stated China is to issue CNY 1tln in special bonds this year and will cut tax and fee burdens for companies by CNY 2.5tln this year although noted China faces unprecedented risks and challenges. China also reiterated its intent to implement phase one of the trade deal with the US despite recent tensions between the two nations. (Newswires)

Chinese Foreign Ministry says that it will fight back if the US attempts to oppress them. (Newswires)

China's draft Hong Kong legislation stated that Hong Kong should finish enacting as soon as possible the regulations in basic law regarding national security. Furthermore, it stated that the Hong Kong government and legal bodies should prevent, stop and punish activities that endanger national security, while the bill is to allow China to set up an agency in Hong Kong to safeguard national security. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam says they are to fully co-operate with China to enact the National Security law as soon as is possible. (Newswires)

Hong Kong activists vow to take to the streets in protest against Beijing plans to impose launches a national security law which is seen as one of its fiercest assaults on Hong Kong's autonomy. (AFP/Twitter)

BoJ kept main policy settings unchanged as expected with NIRP maintained at -0.10% and the 10yr JGB yield target at around 0% through 8-1 vote, while it decided on a new loan scheme aimed at boosting lending to support small and mid-sized firms hit by the coronavirus with the programme worth JPY 75tln. BoJ added that the loans are to be conducted from June and it is to actively purchase ETD and REITS for the time being. (Newswires)

Japanese Government is looking at creating a JPY 12trl safety net to provide capital to firms impacted by COVID-19, according to the Nikkei.

Japanese National CPI (Apr) Y/Y 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Apr) Y/Y -0.2% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 0.4%) Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Apr) Y/Y 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%)

RBI cut the Repurchase Rate by 40bps to 4.00% and Reverse Repo Rate by 40bps to 3.35% in an unscheduled meeting, while it is taking measures on debt relief, supporting trade and steps to ease constraints on state governments. Furthermore, it rolled over the SIBDI facility for another 90 days and Governor Das stated they will continue to be proactive and react to situations as and when it is warranted. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Retail Sales MM* (Apr) -18.1% vs. Exp. -16.0% (Prev. -5.1%, Rev. -5.2%)

UK Retail Sales YY (Apr) -22.6% vs. Exp. -22.2% (Prev. -5.8%)

UK Retail Sales Ex-Fuel YY* (Apr) -18.4% vs. Exp. -18.2% (Prev. -4.1%, Rev. -4.2%)

UK Retail Sales Ex-Fuel MM* (Apr) -15.2% vs. Exp. -15.0% (Prev. -3.7%, Rev. -3.8%)

UK PSNB, GBP* (Apr) 61.4B GB vs. Exp. 35.0B GB (Prev. 2.325B GB, Rev. 14.005B GB)

UK PSNB Ex Banks GBP* (Apr) 62.1B GB vs. Exp. 40.0B GB (Prev. 3.05B GB, Rev. 14.730B GB)

BoE Deputy Governor Ramsden says it is possible BoE will do more QE at the June meeting or subsequently, it is reasonable to have an open mind on negative rates but it is complex. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson is reportedly seeking to end UK reliance on some Chinese imports. (Times)

UK GfK Consumer Confidence (May P) -34 (Prev. -33); lowest since February 2009. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European majors trade mostly negative (Euro Stoxx 50 -0.3%) but have drifted off lows following a dismal APAC handover in which the Hang Seng was pummelled by the prospect of a resurgence in violent pro-democracy protests, whilst Chinese markets were dragged lower in sympathy as the nation is on course for further escalation with the US and as the NPC did not provide a GDP growth target for the year. Back to Europe, peripheries fare better than the core markets, whilst the FTSE 100 (-0.9%) and SMI (-1.4%) lag European peers, albeit the former weighed on by energy, materials and financials and the latter more-so on catch-up play. Sectors are red across the board but do not reflect a clear risk tone as specific sectors take hits on Hong Kong woes - with Financials and Energy underperforming, the latter amid price action in the complex and the former dragged by a lower yield environment alongside Hong Kong-exposed banks plumbing the depths; HSBC (-5.4%) and Standard Chartered (-4.0%). The wide US-China implication and downbeat sentiment prompts materials sector to trade on a poor footing. Fears of protests also see luxury names on the backfoot; LVMH (-1.2%), Kering (-1.2%), Richemont (-3.1%), Swatch (-1.1%) hold onto losses. In terms of other individual movers: Burberry (+1.8%) holds onto gains after the Co. said it can weather the pandemic with a strong balance sheet and protected liquidity. Renault (-2.0%) opened weaker amid little progress with the French gov’t on state aid; Co. are due to meet with Finance Minister Le Maire today.

NVIDIA Corp (NVDA) Q1 20 (USD): Adj. EPS 1.80 (exp. 1.69), Revenue 3.1bln (exp. 3.0bln); authorised USD 7.24bln in share repurchases through Dec. 2022, evaluating timing of share repurchases. Maintains dividend commitment. DCG: 1.14bln (exp. 1.07bln), Q2 revenue view 3.65bln (+/- 2% (exp. 3.28bln).Gaming revenue 1.34bln (exp. 1.29bln; -10% Q/Q, -27% Y/Y) GM: 65.1% (exp. 65.4%). Co. shares fell 0.5% after-market – some desks believe the stock had recently seen significant rally and figures relative to near-term expectations may not be enough to spur upside. N.B. This would also be against the backdrop of US-China trade uncertainty.

Deere & Co (DE) Q1 20 (USD): EPS 2.11 (exp. 1.77), Revenue 8.22bln (exp. 7.79bln). sees FY net income 1.6-2bln (exp. 2.10bln)

FX

USD/CNH - Not the biggest move in percentage terms, but pertinent in the context of gauging the rising level of US-China angst as the pair climbs to highs not seen since March above 7.1600, and closer to record peaks in early September last year when trade wars were raging. Moreover, confirmation that Beijing is not setting an official 2020 growth target and the NPC drafting legislation on national security for Hong Kong have ruffled the Yuan, with the latter also adding yet another point of dispute to the increasingly long list jeopardising already strained relations between the 2 nations. In terms of the wider repercussions, risk sentiment has deteriorated further to the benefit of the Greenback above all rivals bar the Yen, as the DXY extends its rebound from recent lows and at least 2 close scrapes with the 99.000 level to a 99.838 high, and still seemingly on the up.

AUD/CAD/EUR/GBP/NZD - No surprise to see the Aussie bearing the brunt of the latest Washington-Beijing spat, especially as the Hong Kong Dollar is pegged, but Aud/Usd and Aud/Nzd have also retreated in response to Fitch downgrading the sovereign’s triple A ratings outlook to negative from stable. The former is now hovering nearer 0.6500 from 0.6600+ yesterday and the latter is down through 1.0700 compared to a 1.0830 apex earlier in the week, as the Kiwi manages to stay within sight of 0.6100 against its US counterpart following comments from NZ Finance Minister Robertson about formative discussions on the topic of helicopter money. Meanwhile, the Euro has handed back more gains vs the Buck after its fleeting or false break over the 1.1000 mark on Thursday and has been back under the round number below, but not quite far enough to stir hefty option expiry interest between 1.0885-75 in 2.8 bn. Elsewhere, the Loonie has lost its oil prop and trying to contain declines through 1.400 ahead of Canadian retail sales data, and on that very note Cable is straddling 1.2200 and the Eur/Gbp cross 0.8950 after weaker than expected UK consumption rattled Sterling somewhat more than equally bad public sector finances and tripped some stops in the former at 1.2180. However, underlying bids said to be sitting from 1.2160 to 1.2150 have not been troubled so far.

JPY/CHF - As noted above, the Yen is marginally outperforming vs the Greenback, albeit still rangebound either side of 107.50 and only retaining an element of safe-haven premium after no shocks from the inter-schedule BoJ meeting or more recent joint statement from Governor Kuroda and Japanese Finance Minister Aso expanding on the rationale behind new bank lending provisions. Conversely, Usd/Chf remains elevated on the 0.9700 handle, but the Franc is still unwinding losses relative to the Euro and probing 1.0600 ahead of the ECB minutes (full preview available via the headline feed) and next Monday’s Swiss bank sight deposit balance update.

EM - Aside from broad depreciation on risk aversion, the Indian Rupiah got an unexpected 40 bp RBI rate cut to contend with, though Usd/Idr has reversed after a knee-jerk jump to trade lower on the day.

Fitch revised Australia’s Outlook from Stable to Negative, affirmed rating at AAA. (Newswires)

New Zealand Finance Minister Robertson said helicopter money is being discussed but not at a level where we have details how it will work, while he added they are keen to make sure fiscal policy remains with the government. (Newswires)

FIXED

Core bonds have lost momentum coinciding with a grinding recovery in EU stocks that suggests normal inverse asset correlations have comeback in to play at least partially, and of course the debt/equity trade-off is likely to become more compelling into month end, especially as portfolio rebalancing rears again. On that note, one major bank notes an especially lengthy duration extension for US Treasuries that could keep the complex afloat and the curve continue to flatten. However, Bunds have drifted back from 173.52 at best and Gilts from 138.99 ahead of ECB minutes and a blank US agenda into the long holiday weekend that also sees UK markets shut on May 25.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front month futures experience substantial intraday losses as sentiment takes a hit from developments regarding the Hong Kong legislations as well as wider implications such as escalating trade tensions with the US and souring sentiment with the UK. As such, clear risk aversion is seen – with WTI and Brent July around USD 31.50/bbl and 34/bbl, down around 7% and 5% respectively and with current bases at USD 30.70/bbl and USD 33.50/bbl respectively. Spot gold sees haven demand, residing towards the top-end of its USD 1725-38/oz current range. Copper prices gapped lower below USD 2.4/lb and holds onto sentiment-driven losses, with some also attributing the downside to China refraining from assigning a GDP target.

Copper prices gapped lower below USD 2.4/lb and holds onto sentiment-driven losses, with some also attributing the downside to China refraining from assigning a GDP target.

On that note, one major bank notes an especially lengthy duration extension for US Treasuries that could keep the complex afloat and the curve continue to flatten. However, Bunds have drifted back from 173.52 at best and Gilts from 138.99 ahead of ECB minutes and a blank US agenda into the long holiday weekend that also sees UK markets shut on May 25.

FX Morning Colour: Dollar revival continues as US-China contentions escalate
content:
USD/CNH

Not the biggest move in percentage terms, but pertinent in the context of gauging the rising level of US-China angst as the pair climbs to highs not seen since March above 7.1600, and closer to record peaks in early September last year when trade wars were raging. Moreover, confirmation that Beijing is not setting an official 2020 growth target and the NPC drafting legislation on national security for Hong Kong have ruffled the Yuan, with the latter also adding yet another point of dispute to the increasingly long list jeopardising already strained relations between the 2 nations. In terms of the wider repercussions, risk sentiment has deteriorated further to the benefit of the Greenback above all rivals bar the Yen, as the DXY extends its rebound from recent lows and at least 2 close scrapes with the 99.000 level to a 99.838 high, and still seemingly on the up.

AUD/CAD/EUR/GBP/NZD

No surprise to see the Aussie bearing the brunt of the latest Washington-Beijing spat, especially as the Hong Kong Dollar is pegged, but Aud/Usd and Aud/Nzd have also retreated in response to Fitch downgrading the sovereign’s triple A ratings outlook to negative from stable. The former is now hovering nearer 0.6500 from 0.6600+ yesterday and the latter is down through 1.0700 compared to a 1.0830 apex earlier in the week, as the Kiwi manages to stay within sight of 0.6100 against its US counterpart following comments from NZ Finance Minister Robertson about formative discussions on the topic of helicopter money. Meanwhile, the Euro has handed back more gains vs the Buck after its fleeting or false break over the 1.1000 mark on Thursday and has been back under the round number below, but not quite far enough to stir hefty option expiry interest between 1.0885-75 in 2.8 bn. Elsewhere, the Loonie has lost its oil prop and trying to contain declines through 1.400 ahead of Canadian retail sales data, and on that very note Cable is straddling 1.2200 and the Eur/Gbp cross 0.8950 after weaker than expected UK consumption rattled Sterling somewhat more than equally bad public sector finances and tripped some stops in the former at 1.2180. However, underlying bids said to be sitting from 1.2160 to 1.2150 have not been troubled so far.

JPY/CHF

As noted above, the Yen is marginally outperforming vs the Greenback, albeit still rangebound either side of 107.50 and only retaining an element of safe-haven premium after no shocks from the inter-schedule BoJ meeting or more recent joint statement from Governor Kuroda and Japanese Finance Minister Aso expanding on the rationale behind new bank lending provisions. Conversely, Usd/Chf remains elevated on the 0.9700 handle, but the Franc is still unwinding losses relative to the Euro and probing 1.0600 ahead of the ECB minutes (full preview available via the headline feed) and next Monday’s Swiss bank sight deposit balance update.

EM 

Aside from broad depreciation on risk aversion, the Indian Rupiah got an unexpected 40 bp RBI rate cut to contend with, though Usd/Idr has reversed after a knee-jerk jump to trade lower on the day.

US PRE-MARKET THEMES: Risk sentiment knocked after China security law; ECB minutes ahead; long-weekend(s) may see liquidity tail-off in the afternoon
analysis_details:
SNAPSHOT: Chinese equities were under pressure overnight after Beijing announced a security law which could allow it to bypass Hong Kong lawmakers to crackdown on dissent, and that has hit risk sentiment. Europe is softer (non-cyclicals and tech getting hit), and US equity futures slumped, though the 2,900 in ES held overnight, and we have pared back off lows in the European morning. Treasuries are bull-flattening, the dollar is up for a second day, putting pressure on EMFX and risk sensitive currencies, and even oil is taking its cues from the risk complex today despite bullish inventory data over the last two weeks. Ahead, ECB minutes are released at 0730 EDT/1230 BST (preview here), and the NY Fed will announce next week's asset purchase schedule at 1400 EDT/1900 BST (preview); we expect liquidity conditions to tail-off in the afternoon as US and UK players eye a long-weekend (see below for market and desk hours).

CHINA: China Premier Li Keqiang announced Beijing would scrap its growth target this year, and introduced national security law which allows it to bypass Hong Kong's lawmakers, which pro-democracy activists fear it could mean the effective end of Hong Kong’s autonomy. In terms of the economic metrics, it abandoned its 2020 GDP target due to the COVID19 pandemic and uncertainties. It is, however, targeting a fiscal deficit of 3.6%/GDP (from 2.8% in 2019), which some analysts have taken as a sign that China does not intend to significantly ramp up fiscal stimulus. China aims to create 9mln jobs in 2020 (it’s 2019 target was 11mln), and joblessness will be capped at 6%. China also fixed the quota on local-government special bond issuance at CNY 3.75trln (prev. CNY 2.15trln). It will debut 1trln of special treasury bonds in 2020, and transfer CNY 2trln raised from the bigger 2020 budget deficit and special anti-coronavirus treasury bonds to local governments, Reuters reported. These local government bonds could be used to fund infrastructure projects, while special treasury bonds could be used to support firms and regions hit by the outbreak. A Reuters calculation suggests these fiscal measures are worth about 4.1% of china's GDP.

ES LEVELS: 3,135 (78.6% Feb hi-Mar lo), 2,998 (200dma), 2,976.25 (May hi), 2,950-53 (volume profile), 2,947-50 (FY 20 and FY 21 exp EPS and p/e implied valuations), 2,940 (5dma), 2,930 (61.8% Feb hi-Mar lo), 2,917-2,923, 2,900-10 (volume profile), 2,900 (8dma), 2,894 (13dma), 2,850 (this week lo).

FUND FLOWS: Bank of America’s weekly fund flow analysis of EPFR data reveals that investor cash stockpiling see during the COVID outbreak has peaked, with cash focussed funds seeing outflows of USD 5.9bln in the week, the first outflows since mid-February; equity funds saw outflows of USD 7.6bln, BofA says, the first decline in 12-weeks, and bond funds saw the largest inflows in 13-weeks, while gold funds saw inflows of USD 3.5bln, a record. 

EARNINGS: Decent earnings from Nvidia (NVDA), though it couldn’t sustain gains in after hours trade, with analysts suggesting that traders were taking profits after a decent run; others suggested like RBC suggested that the Mellanox guide for next quarter was light. Palo Alto Networks (PANW) was also a strong report, while the next quarter’s guidance was also encouraging. Hewlett Packard Enterprises (HPE) was disappointing on most metrics. This morning, we have earnings from BABA, DE and FL due, preview here.

GROWTH, MOMENTUM STILL PREFERRED: US equities have this week printed fresh May highs earlier in the week, and then slumped in the latter part as US/China risk sentiment deteriorated. Nomura's quants think the improvement in sentiment will not take a breather, although points out that technically foreseeable risk-off phases tend to not last too long: "Bearish investors that had been counting on a stock market double dip already appear to be backing out of the trades they had made on that assumption, and it seems that few investors are attempting to chase the market down," the bank says, "it may make sense for now to buy whatever dips come along and wait to see what happens." Nomura says that CTAs seem reticent to tweak positions much, and NDX futures are the only US equity futures where CTAs have already gone back to accumulating longs. "Given that the NASDAQ 100 is the only US stock market index in a clear uptrend, we soon expect to see CTAs plainly building up their net long position again, perhaps even next week although possibly not until 5 June." Growth and momentum appear to be the preferred strategies, the quants say, given that 10-year yields are beneath what it calls the 'trigger line' of 0.84% and US economic surprises are not yet improving, investors seem to be sticking with momentum for a lack of better alternatives. Nomura sees global macro hedge funds actively staking out new positions, premised on a main scenario in which the US-China stand-off intensifies. "This leaves hedge funds fairly neutrally positioned with regard to US-China risk; a flare-up in the stand-off still stands as a tail risk, however, and should this risk materialise, these hedge funds could end up taking a punch that is difficult to roll with." Meanwhile, CTA exposure to China-related equity futures (total for China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan) is essentially flat, Nomura says, and it sees no increase in technically driven downside trades. "However, if we look at the relative performance of cyclicals over defensives in cash equity markets, we find that the pick-up in the performance of cyclicals has been weak in Asia, and what this suggests to us that that the market thinks the US economy will recover more quickly than the economies of Asia."

LONG-WEEKEND NOTICE: It is worth noting that there are long-weekends for US and UK players, and accordingly liquidity conditions may tail off in the latter part of the day, and on Monday. Due to the upcoming UK bank holiday and US Memorial Day holiday on Monday 25th May, the desk will be running a reduced service alongside the subsequent market closures. On Sunday May 24th the Asia-Pacific service will open at its regular time of 2200BST/1600CDT with the European service also opening at its regular time of 0630BST/0030CDT on Monday 25th May given that European markets will be open for trade. The European service will run to 1800BST, upon which the desk will close. Note, there will be no US service thereafter for that session due to US market closures. The service will then re-open later that evening on May 25th at 2200BST for the beginning of the Asia-Pacific session with full coverage to resume thereafter on Tuesday May 26th. In terms of market opening hours: In the UK, all UK products are closed; in Europe there is regular trading; in the US, Friday 22nd May 2020 floor trade early close at 1200CDT/1800BST, and on Monday 25th May 2020 it is closed. Electronic Trade (Monday 25th May 2020) will see equity closed 1200CDT/1800BST, Re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST, interest rate products closed 1200CDT/1800BST, re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST, FX closes 1200CDT/1800BST, and re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST; NYMEX closed 1200CDT/1800BST, re-opens 1700CDT/2300BST.

subject: PRIMER: ECB April Minutes due to be released Friday 22nd May at 1230BST/0630CDT
content: The latest policy announcement from the ECB saw policymakers opt to stand pat on rates once again with the general train of thought at the Bank being that delving deeper into negative territory at this stage would provide little in the way of stimulus for the Eurozone. Instead, the Governing Council opted to sweeten the terms of the existing TLTROIII operations and launch a new series of non-targeted pandemic emergency longer-term refinancing operations (PELTROs) with the view of supporting liquidity conditions in the euro area. Those hoping for an expansion of the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP) were left somewhat disappointed with the current envelope left at a size of EUR 750bln, whilst the asset purchase programme (APP) will continue to run at a monthly pace of EUR 20bln. That said, the Governing Council was explicit in informing market participants that it “is fully prepared to increase the size of the PEPP and adjust its composition, by as much as necessary and for as long as needed”; any further clarity on this front will be of interest to participants. At the accompanying press conference, Lagarde provided a relatively cautious introductory statement, as expected, whilst stopping short of specific forecasts on the macro outlook; staff economic projections are not due until the June meeting; analysts will be eyeing the account for any further qualitative comments by policymakers on the Eurozone’s growth outlook. Lagarde took every opportunity to remind those watching that the Governing Council will be there to help support the Eurozone economy, however policy will need to be carried out in a coordinated manner with fiscal authorities. Heading into the announcement some desks had speculated about the possibility of yield curve control (YCC), on which, Lagarde stated, the combination of tools the ECB is currently using enables it to operate across the entire curve; but noted the ECB will use all the flexibility that it has. Elsewhere, despite some slightly incoherent responses during the Q&A segment (in a bid to avoid any faux paus such as that seen in March), the press conference wasn’t too much of a game-changer for the narrative surrounding the Bank’s current course of action.

Market contacts also flag up technical resistance nearby between 173.42-48 ahead of 173.60, but Bunds look set to bide some time pending Friday’s EU cash bourse opens to see whether more safe-haven premium is warranted or debt and equities diverge again. Ahead, ECB minutes and a speech from chief economist Lane are scheduled and could provide a distraction amidst the ongoing COVID-19 vigil with detrimental repercussions on the US-China relationship front.

ASIA

Asian indices weakened as markets digested today's key events including the BoJ off-schedule meeting and start of China's NPC where it omitted setting a GDP growth target for this year due to the coronavirus pandemic, as well as uncertainties surrounding economy and trade. (-1.3%) were lower amid the start of China’s Two Sessions conclave where the Government Work Report refrained from setting an economic growth target but pledged to reduce tax and fee burdens for companies by CNY 2.5tln this year and use several tools to keep liquidity ample. Furthermore, the losses in Hong Kong were exacerbated after China’s attempts to tighten its grip on the Special Administrative Region through a new national security law, and is likely to stoke further unrest for the region which had already been mired by months of protests since the middle of last year.
